Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCING Intersectionality: An Analysis of Underrepresented Minorities in NSF ADVANCE Programming

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed collaborative project from Lafayette College and California Polytechnic State University is rooted in the theory of intersectionality as it relates to gender and race/ethnicity. The project has three major objectives that include assessing the attentiveness of recent ADVANCE programs to issues germane to women of color, examining the rationale of those strategies utilized in addressing the underrepresentation of women of color and identifying successful practices and strategies that have been successfully implemented in the ADVANCE program. This project, which represents the first systematic exploration of the ADVANCE program and its focus on women of color will combine a pilot study, funded proposal content analysis and interviews with funded ADVANCE project personnel. It is expected that the outcomes of this effort will support the ADVANCE program in promoting inclusiveness as it relates to gender equity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF ADVANCE PAID research grant was collaborative with NSF ID# 1207250 (J. Jovanovic, PI-Cal Poly SLO) and focused on better understanding the opportunities and challenges that emerge from intersectional approaches to achieving equity through institutional change. Focusing on the persistent lag faced by underrepresented minority (URM) women in US academic science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields, this project had two specific over-arching goals: 1) to contribute to current research on enabling URM women in academic STEM fields and 2) to advance broader current discussions concerning how intersectional approaches might be applied to shape institutional transformation. 

Because intersectional analysis offers an approach that simultaneously addresses multiple forms of subordinate identities, we began with the premise that intersectionality could offer new insights into the seemingly intractable institutional dynamics that have stymied the progress of many URM women in STEM fields.  Our project tracked the efforts of the 3rd and 4th cohorts of institutions awarded NSF ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (IT) grants. Two core research goals were to assess these ADVANCE programs' overall attentiveness to issues faced by URM women in STEM and identify the IT's documented strategies for addressing these issues. We also hoped to identify emergent successful practices and strategies for supporting URM women in STEM.

We focused on two forms of data:
1. Program Documentation and Records: Documents included the ITs' original NSF ADVANCE proposals, along with annual reports and external evaluations. We used standard content analysis procedures to qualitatively measure evidence of interest in and development of diversity-related initiatives, paying attention to those that considered the intersections of gender with other URM identities. We drew from the work by Diana Bilimoria and her colleagues (who developed a comprehensive assessment of transformational initiatives in the first- and second-round ADVANCE ITs) (Bilimoria, Joy, and Liang, 2008). We used Bilimoria's approach to identifying initiatives to develop our set of codes, which we then applied to our document analysis.
2. Viewpoints and Input from ADVANCE Program Staff:  Findings from our document analyses formed the basis of conversations with ADVANCE IT staff, which incorporated basic questions that we posed to all ITs and questions specific to the program activities identified in our institutionally-specific document analyses. A central question was, "What do you identify as the single most important institutional enabler/institutional barrier to successfully supporting URM women at your institution?"

Our work revealed a pattern of barriers and challenges faced by universities trying to promote institutional change for women at the intersections of multiple identities. Informed by IT staff conversations, we identified 5 key "Intersectional Facilitators" (IFs) that emerge from these challenges (and, in some cases, successes). The 5 IFs are: Accountable Leadership, Identifying Climate Zones, Understanding the (N)umbers Game, Overcoming Epistemological Hurdles, and Promoting Community Structures. We believe these 5 IFs, complexly understood, offer innovative ways of thinking about change that can then drive new strategies for practical intervention.

Additionally, data from our content analysis of IT program documents combined with data from out IT conversations provided new insights and revealed patterns related to fostering institutional change for URM women in STEM, including:
* The blurring effect, where initiatives intended to empower URM women are captured (and sometimes dissipate) within a generic "women in STEM" initiative. Rather than consistently targeting an intersectional point, initiatives often fall back into the inclusion model by default. We posit this is because key characteristics of URM women's experiences remain persistently invisible without a contextualized, intersectional perspective.
* The intent-implementation gap, a disconnect between wanting to support URM women (e.g., "intersectional ambitions") and actual intersectional initiatives. The "intent-implementation gap" illuminates the hard-to-articulate structural space where gender and race must be simultaneously taken into account.  If an intersectional perspective is not taken, that structural space is harder to name and address.
* The "For Who?" problem, a frequent reliance on the assumption that a general initiative intended to support women in STEM is "likely also" to be useful to URM women. Relatedly, some institutions launch initiatives for URM women on the assumption that it will help that particular group-without any contextual, intersectional knowledge or locally-based evidence for that assumption.

Our theoretical and methodological approach had intellectual merit because it employed the full spectrum of research in this area, uniting scholarly work focusing on the advancement of URM women in STEM with a sophisticated theoretical model (intersectionality) that deems multiple aspects of identity as mutually constitutive in their meanings and effects. Over the course of the work of this grant we actively disseminated outcomes to ensure that our work and findings had broader impact. These included two publications (in Peer Review and Journal of Women and Minorities in Science and Engineering), and three conference representations in various interdisciplinary venues.  A second article is currently in process and is intended for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.
